docs.lead_paragraph: Along with neat cubbies and welcome signs, preschoolers starting the year in the Addie Mae Collins Community Service Head Start program this week were greeted by something new -- two security guards. The guards are there not only to protect the children, but also to keep the adults apart. Members of the program's parent committee say that a new director of the program, in the heart of the Jackie Robinson public housing complex on East 129th Street, has dismantled the civic role it has long played in their community, inappropriately cut them out of decision making and harmed the quality of its education.

headline.main: In Feud Over Head Start, Guards Are Posted at the Door

docs.abstract: Parents of pre-schoolers complain that Cecilia Dauway, new director of Addie Mae Collins Community Service Head Start program in Harlem, has dismantled program's longtime community role, cut them out of decision making and harmed quality of education; some complaints cited; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: At nearly every campaign stop, Howard Dean says most Americans would happily pay as much taxes as they paid under Bill Clinton if they could have the same economy they had in the Clinton years. Dr. Dean, former governor of Vermont, advocates repealing all of President Bush's tax cuts and using the money for universal health insurance, domestic security and job creation.

headline.main: Tax Cuts Split the Democratic Presidential Field

docs.abstract: Democratic presidential contenders are all critical of Pres Bush's tax policy, but part ways on question of any tax-cut rollback; Dr Howard Dean and Rep Richard Gephardt would repeal all tax cuts enacted in last three years, while Sens John Kerry and Joseph Lieberman would do away only with tax cuts for the wealthy; Kerry photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The faculty union at Long Island University's Brooklyn campus, which went on strike last week, agreed yesterday to return to work today after negotiators reached a tentative contract agreement. Ralph Engelman, a journalism professor and strike coordinator for the union, said the proposed agreement was recommended by the union's executive committee. Dr. Engelman said the proposal called for salary increases of 2 percent in the first year and 4 percent in each of the following two years, and would reduce the standard faculty workload from four courses a semester to three, beginning a year from now. Members will vote on the proposed settlement today.

headline.main: Striking L.I.U. Faculty Members Agree to Return to Classrooms

docs.abstract: Faculty union at Long Island University's Brooklyn campus agrees to return to work after negotiators reach tentative contract agreement; proposal calls for salary increases and reduces standard faculty workload (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The police in Paris said they smashed a ring of unlicensed dentists, arresting 23 Syrians who practiced at cafes and grocery stores with battery-operated drills. The ring served a mainly immigrant clientele without health insurance, the police said.

headline.main: World Briefing | Europe: France: Back-Street Fillings

docs.abstract: Paris (France) police arrest 23 Syrians using stores and cafes for unlicensed dental practices; clients are mainly immigrants without insurance (S)
docs.snippet: The police in Paris said they smashed a ring of unlicensed dentists, arresting 23 Syrians who practiced at cafes and grocery stores with battery-operated drills. The ring served a mainly immigrant clientele without health insurance, the police said.

docs.lead_paragraph: Welfare legislation cleared a major hurdle today as the Senate Finance Committee approved a bill that would increase work requirements for welfare recipients. The bill, approved on a party-line vote of 9 to 8, would also spend $1 billion over the next five years to promote marriage as a goal for people on welfare.

headline.main: Bill on Changes in Welfare Advances to Full Senate

docs.abstract: Senate Finance Committee approves bill that would increase work requirements for welfare recipients; House approved similar bill in Feb; both bills make fundamental changes in 1996 welfare law, which has prompted millions of poor people to move from welfare to work; it is unclear when full Senate may take up measure; major provisions of 1996 law expire on Sept 30, but Congress could extend them for few months; Democrats and one Republican on Senate Finance Committe, Sen Olympia J Snowe, say bill does not provide enough money for child care; General Accounting Office says nearly half the states have reduced child-care subsidies or restricted eligibilty in last two years (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Federal law enforcement officials are investigating possible Medicare fraud at HealthSouth, the troubled chain of rehabilitation and surgery centers, after a Texas jury awarded $1.5 million in damages to the former medical director of a Houston hospital, officials said yesterday. Violations of federal Medicare regulations, if proved, could be punished by fines and even loss of Medicare accreditation. Government investigators said they were looking for patterns of wrongdoing in the extensive system of HealthSouth hospitals and centers after obtaining admissions of fraudulent behavior by former executives at the company's headquarters in Birmingham, Ala.

headline.main: Troubled HealthSouth Faces Medicare Fraud Investigation

docs.abstract: Federal law enforcement officials are investigating possible Medicare fraud at HealthSouth Corp after Texas jury awards $1.5 million in damages to Dr Helen Schilling, former director of Houston hospital; violations of federal Medicare regulations, if proved, could be punished by fines and even loss of Medicare accreditation; Schilling says HealthSouth fired her after she did not follow orders to admit patients who did not meet Medicare criteria; HealthSouth says it will ask Judge Mike Mayes to overturn verdict; HealthSouth lawyer Jeffrey S Davis says Schilling misunderstood orders; House Energy and Commerce Committee sends three investigators to HealthSouth's headquarters to look for Medicare fraud and other possible violations; HealthSouth spokesman Andrew Brimmer says company takes all matters related to Medicare seriously and is cooperating with all government inquiries (M)
docs.snippet: Federal law enforcement officials are investigating possible Medicare fraud at HealthSouth, the troubled chain of rehabilitation and surgery centers, after a Texas jury awarded $1.5 million in damages to the former medical director of a Houston...

docs.lead_paragraph: People in employer-sponsored health plans are paying 48 percent more out of their own pockets for care than they did three years ago, according to an authoritative new study, and the cost will be even higher next year. Almost two-thirds of large employers raised the amounts that employees are contributing to the cost of their health plans this year, and 79 percent say they will do so again in 2004, according to the study, by the Kaiser Family Foundation and the Health Research and Educational Trust.

headline.main: EMPLOYEES PAYING EVER-BIGGER SHARE FOR HEALTH CARE

docs.abstract: Study by Kaiser Family Foundation and Health Research and Educational Trust finds almost two-thirds of large employers raised amounts employees contribute to cost of their health plans this year and 79 percent plan to do so again in 2004; employees are now paying 48 percent more out of pocket for care, average of $2,790 for employee with family coverage, than they did in 2000; premiums rose 13.9 percent in 2003; employers still pay bulk of costs, typically at least 75 percent; graph of rises in out-of-pocket costs (M)
docs.snippet: People in employer-sponsored health plans are paying 48 percent more out of their own pockets for care than they did three years ago, according to an authoritative new study, and the cost will be even higher next year.     Almost two-thirds of large...

docs.lead_paragraph: The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Boston agreed today to pay $85 million to settle almost 550 lawsuits by people who say they were sexually abused by priests. The settlement is the largest ever by an American diocese to resolve sexual abuse cases. The deal was reached after three days of intense negotiations, and it represents a personal triumph for Boston's new archbishop, Sean P. O'Malley, who in a highly unusual gesture met with lawyers and mediators on Sunday in a secret session that lasted till midnight.

headline.main: CHURCH IN BOSTON TO PAY $85 MILLION IN ABUSE LAWSUITS

docs.abstract: Boston Roman Catholic Archdiocese agrees to pay $85 million to settle almost 550 suits by people who say they were sexually abused by priests, largest settlment ever by American diocese to resolve sexual abuse cases; deal is triumph for Abp Sean P O'Malley, who, in highly unusual gesture, met secretly with lawyers and mediators; each victim will get $80,000 to $300,000, depending on type and duration of abuse; archdiocese will also finance psychological counseling for victims; photo (M)
docs.snippet: The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Boston agreed today to pay $85 million to settle almost 550 lawsuits by people who say they were sexually abused by priests. The settlement is the largest ever by an American diocese to resolve sexual abuse cases.   ...

docs.lead_paragraph: Employees Pay 48% More For Company Health Plans People in employer-sponsored health plans are paying 48 percent more out of their own pockets for care than they did three years ago, according to a study by the Kaiser Family Foundation and the Health Research and Educational Trust. Almost two-thirds of large employers raised the amounts that employees are contributing to the cost of their health plans this year, and 79 percent say they will do so again in 2004. Other health care experts are projecting that 2004 will be the fourth consecutive year of double-digit increases in health insurance premiums. [Page A1.]

docs.lead_paragraph: In a small but potentially significant step, House and Senate negotiators voted today to help elderly people buy prescription drugs with discount cards endorsed by the federal government. The cards are similar to ones proposed by President Bush in July 2001. They would provide temporary assistance to most Medicare beneficiaries in 2004 and 2005, before Medicare itself would provide drug benefits in 2006.

headline.main: Congressional Committee Agrees on Drug Benefits
